segments.text: I see the woman polishing that plate, her movements methodical and almost hypnotic.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: She seems so lost in her task, and it makes me a bit envious in a way.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: But the water continues to overflow, and with each second, the puddle spreads wider.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: It’s maddening how she doesn’t notice; the worry gnaws at me like a rat in the dark.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: And then there’s the boy, climbing up the stool like it’s the most natural thing in the world.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: It’s like he’s in a world of his own, focused on the cookie jar while danger lurks beneath him.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The girl looks so hopeful with her hand raised, and I feel a pang of compassion.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: They’re just kids, after all, filled with a sense of adventure, and I can’t help but smile at their innocence.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: But that smile fades quickly when I think about what might happen if the stool gives way.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The whole scene feels like a ticking clock, every moment bringing us closer to a potential disaster.
segments.speaker: PAR
